reviewText: I almost gave this one or two stars, but then I realized that some people actually like bad movies (myself included). While this one isn't a "classic" bad movie, it has some borderline moments.The plot revolves around a family that needs a guard dog, a former police dog that needs a second chance, and some inept home robbers. Those elements should have been enough to make a very good film.Unfortunately, there are a lot of problems with the movie.- The acting (by humans) is absolutely atrocious. It was 1/3 of the way through the film before I realized that it was supposed to be a comedy. The comic timing was off, the actor's delivery was off, and the film plot didn't make it clear that you were supposed to be laughing at what was happening on screen. Because it wasn't designed as a drama, it ended up not working as drama or comedy. What that makes it, I have no idea, except perhaps "a mess".- All the scenes with Grandma were just annoying.- I'm not sure what happened to Ms. Donovan's face, but it looked like some bad plastic surgery. I don't know if it was the lips or what, but everyone watching the move agreed that the effect was almost scary. I hate to mention such a thing, but it really hit the viewer, so it needs to be mentioned.- The plot was merely adequate. On a project like this the viewer pretty much knows what is going to happen, but a few plot twists would have been nice to mix things up. As it was, the acting did not cover up the plainness of the plot.One the good side:- The dog was cute (except that the dog actor was a female, and the camera angles made this apparent, even though the plot called for a male dog). The other dogs were also nice.- The film was fairly well paced.- Some of the comic moments were OK, especially when the crooks were in the house.- This would not bother some people, but the movie was shot in our locale of Los Angeles, specifically the San Fernando / Santa Clarita valley, and it was really interesting to see how they drove to Grandma's house via what appeared to be the Angeles Crest highway. In real life they would have gone many, many miles. I suppose it was actually humerous.- This was obviously a low budget film. Be sure and watch the credits; we had a blast reading all those names. It appears that all the extras were from the families of the film crew. This may account for some of the acting problems.In summary, it isn't charming or cute, it has some good moments, and it is on the borderline of being so bad that it is good. I don't recommend it as an annual Christmas movie!
summary: View it as a comedy, including the production values
Title: N/A

reviewText: I actually received this just after Christmas, by which time we were already knee deep in Holiday movies, but the kids love them so I thought what the heck.I gave it three stars, that may sound mean, but it's a stock Christmas movie, what else can you say.You've seen the same plot a thousand times in different forms, this time it's the dog that brings everyone together, amid much oohs and aahhs, and snuggling around the fire.Don't expect a ton of action, although there are enough canine capers, and funny moments to keep most everyone content (mostly at the extreme ends of the age scale) who like this gentle kind of stuff.Will Zeus the ex K-9 patrol dog, ever get back his bark? Will be be left homeless this Christmas? You don't need to be Einstein to figure it out.I'm not being overly critical, I mean the acting is pretty good, production doesn't look cheap, and it is the season after all. I used to bemoan these flicks a lot when I was younger, but it's actually nice to watch kids following this kind of stuff, rather than explosions, Sfx and violence for a change.
summary: Lifestyle schamltz, kids will like it

reviewText: This ABC Family TV movie is a cross between "Home Alone", "Marley and Me" and "Look Who's Talking" - with all the worst elements of each. Zeus is a former K-9 police dog who's rescued from a shelter by a family looking for a good watchdog.  After falling short of expectations, and threatened with returning to the pound, he redeems himself by thwarting two bumbling burglars (Dean Cain and Joey Diaz).  Speaking of falling short of expectations, this predictable and painfully unfunny film does just that, even for the standards of an ABC Family movie. The acting and direction are generally bad - Gary Valentine, who plays the dad, is a poor man's Kevin James (and is in fact James' brother).  Elisa Donovan resembles a younger, less funny Catherine O'Hara; and the actors playing the kids seem too old for their roles.  Even the dog's voice (Mario Lopez) is annoying, though Zeus is somewhat charming in a mature-Lab kind of way.  The "Cat Lady" (Adrienne Barbeau), a misunderstood neighbor who helps Zeus face his fears, and the grandma who sings karaoke (Mindy Sterling), are perhaps the two most interesting characters and give the film at least a few non-cliched moments.  And the pet mice have a couple of good lines. Will your kids like it?  Maybe, if they're young and undiscriminating, and if they love dogs, Christmas, and bad slapstick.
summary: This Dog Won't Save Anyone's Christmas:  One and a half stars

reviewText: Wow, this one may be good intentioned but it's really bad. It's kind of like watching a skit on Saturday Night Live (SNL), you know what I mean, one of those little parodies where everyone is trying their best not to laugh out loud at the absurdity of the storyline. Only in the case of 'The Dog Who Saved Christmas there's absolutely nothing funny to laugh about.Definitely not for adults but maybe something children (5 and under) might enjoy. reviewText: I grabbed this for my kids to watch with their cousins while we were visiting family out of state for the holidays. I thought it would be a cute movie that would fit all ages (10-6). I was right! The kids loved it and talked about it off and on for several days afterwards with much laughter. That made it very special. My son told me that it was a lot like Home Alone.Recently, I was able to watch it and... yes, it's like Home alone - with a dog. As an adult, I thought it was just okay, but I'm rating it higher because the kids liked it so much and really, it's about them, ya know?This is good for people that are looking for a holiday film. It's pretty mild, so it would be fine for something for the adults to watch with the kids and everyone enjoy it, it's not too adult or too kid-oriented, so it fits the bill nicely.Worth a watch, but a familiar storyline :)

The Father didn't act like he could possibly do anything that would put him in that income bracket. Perhaps he earned it the old fashioned way: he inherited it. Yet another argument for family planning.

reviewText: The Dog Who Saved Christmas is not sooooo bad that it's funny; it's just bad enough that it is not funny. C actors agreed to do this film; they exited on the D list.Zeus is a sad dog that turns himself into the dog pound, at least he'll get three meals a day. He meets a group of talking dogs and we learn that Zeus used to be a rescue dog. We then meet the Bannister family at Christmas time. They need a guard dog, but Mom Bannister doesn't want a dog. Dad Bannister decides to get a dog from the pound. Zeus is the lucky dog. All the fun starts there!!!The movie had some potential, Zeus the dog is a cute Labrador retriever. Talking dogs!! Air Bud, cute dog series? The idea is cute, adopt a dog from the pound and the family will just love it to pieces and have a happy Christmas. The execution is something altogether different.At one point my wife summed up the film perfectly, this is a documentary on how not to make a movie.We've gotten used to special effects. Not in this film, there is exactly one special effect, the moon setting over the house. The dogs talk in our imagination, or without moving their mouths. So there are these awful jiggly, out of focus, shots of dogs standing around with voice over narration. Oh, even white mice and cats get in the act. Occasionally the camera is turned around and gives us the dog point of view of people talking to them.An indication that this is a bad movie, I noticed that the prop person, hired to wash the car windows, never washed the car windows in the first car scene. I noticed dirty windows. It's not clear what Mr. Bannister does for a living, but it's pretty clear he's not a surgeon. In the background of their upstairs library is a copy of "Thoracic Surgery" and the "PC Bible". Clearly, the house was rented from a surgeon.The worst continuity problem was in the last scene. The family walks outside in broad dailight. They meet the "Cat Lady" next door just outside their fence. The Cat Lady is in progressively darker light. They cut back and forth between early dusk and bright sunlight of the family. Finally, Cat Lady asks the family a question, and the family is now in the dark with Christmas lights all lit up. This conversation was about 6 lines, maybe 30 seconds in real time.The acting is pitiful. The camera work is even worse, with many out of focus shots, and horrible handheld camera wiggling all over. Editing was bad. And the story line was just full of so many holes, it was laughable.Let me assemble the cast. The director, Michael Feifer, specializes in gruesome murderer movies, BTK, Bundy and American Icon, Chicago Massacre: Richard Speck; horror movies, Grim Reaper, The Butcher, and The Graveyard. Gary Valentine (Kevin James real life brother, plays Doug's brother on the King of Queens) plays Dad Bannister. Charlie Stewart, A Suite Life, Disney star plays the oldest son that is supposed to be about 13, but looks 19 (and is 16 in real life). Elisa Donovan, Sabrina the Teenage Witch, plays Mrs. Bannister looking about 15 years younger than her husband. Mario Lopez, Saved by the Bell, is Zeus' voice. There is exactly one person that can act in this mess, and she has a small part; Adrienne Barbeau (a fairly large sex symbol in the 70's and 80's) plays the Cat Lady.The film was shot in California and Christmas is very green. But the Police car and the thieves' van have Connecticut license plates.This is an hour and a half movie that is just way too long. It is rated PG. Watch out for the little kids, the dogs in the pound are held in what looks like a real prison, huge bars and all. Otherwise, this film is family friendly. It's a pretty good indication that a film is bad when not funny deleted scenes are played just before the credits. How many times can you watch an actor laugh flubbing their lines? Clearly not enough, according to the director of this film. Anchor Bay Entertainment has released some really bad movies in recent memory.Pass on this mess. They tried way too hard to be funny. And they missed the mark by a long margin.
summary: Tried Too Hard To Be Cute
Title: N/A

reviewText: The plot is "Home Alone" with a dog in the leading role instead of a boy. The film receives a big boost from Mario Lopez's spirited and zesty "vocal performance" as the voice of Zeus (like the Greek God). Zeus is a former police dog now looking for a good home.  Zeus tries hard to prove he deserves a place in the Bannister household. Trouble is, Zeus can't bark due to a traumatic incident while he was working as a police dog. Dad (Gary Valentine from "The King Of Queens") and the kids love Zeus instantly, but the wife/mom thinks he is less than ideal as a guard dog and should be taken back to the pound (after Christmas is over, of course). While the family is away visting Grandma, two bumbling burglers, straight out of "The World's Dumbest Criminals," break in and Zeus, finally, finds his "voice."If nothing else, "Dog" proves that Dean Cain's star has sadly slipped since his high-flying debut as Superman on "Lois And Clark", and his impressive turn as a gay player in "The Broken Hearts Club." Dean Cain, bless him, apparently has no dignity left and will play ANY role in ANYTHING for a paycheck. All flaws might easily be forgiven if this big-hearted, well-intentioned film did not rely so heavily on " excessive toilet humor" for "laughs."Still, this "Dog" is nowhere near as deadly and bad as 2009's other "talking dogs at Christmas" DVD,  "Santa's Buddies." "Maude's" Adrienne Barbeau has a supporting role as a supposedly "mean" lady in the neighborhood who hates dogs; and Mindy Sterling, from the "Austin Powers" movies, is an especially wacky Grandma.
summary: GOOD-HEARTED DOG/CHRISTMAS FILM SPOILED BY TOO MUCH "TOILET HUMOR."

reviewText: The story is pretty straight-forward (please read description on product page) and the movie is oh so predictable. As the title implies, the dog who used to be a "top" K-9 dog  has since "lost" his bark (traumatic incident), and is on the verge of being taken back to the pound (he destroyed a gingerbread house that they spent 2 weeks on - OH  NO !). The family is so mad at him that they decide to leave poor Zeus "home alone" on Christmas Eve while they go to grandma's house. It was a good thing though because two bungling burglars decided to rob them and ruin Christmas! Admittedly, there are some funny scenes (and crude humor-think bodily noises) but my girls both enjoyed the movie. I could barely tolerate it between the bad acting (by Zeus' family) and the unrealistic plot - What robbers stay at a house for over 2 hours ?!? And there were just some plain, weird scenes like when the dad is in the tub with the dog saying "I know it's awkward at first but...". In conclusion, I would certainly not purchase this movie. I do think your kids might enjoy it as a rental, preferably the $1 kind.
summary: It's typical cheesy kids' movies ...and yes, the kids liked it !

reviewText: I generally collect Holiday movies and animation shows. Most are very well done. Well, there are the exceptions - this is it.The production value was a little on the 'student film' style. Choppy editing, framing and composition of shot seem not to match and the dialogue was almost infantile and predictable.Mario Lopez - who is nothing more than the voice of the Dog "Zeus"- seemed to be having fun - at least as seen in the behind the scenes recordings they showed - but the rest of the cast was tired and stale. Mario was reading with gusto - but it didn't translate onto the small screen.There are two exceptions - Adrienne Barbeau (Creepshow) as the Cat Lady and the stellar performance of Mindy Sterling (Austin Powers Movies) as the overbearing and impossibly annoying Grandma.Another small - but 'real' acting charm was Dean Cain. In fact he seemed to be the only one really acting for acting. While Adrienne was the emotional core - who did give a short heartwarming back-story to fill in the mystery that is her character, with the exception of those I mentioned - the rest of the cast was week.Dean Cain (Superman of Lois & Clark) was trying to make it real - however his supporting star couldn't hold a candle to Mr. Cain's acting chops!It was trying to be a Home Alone, but with a dog. It didn't quite reach the mark. Good for the toddlers - but I can see adults dozing off. 1-14-10
summary: A Little Weak For The Holidays!

reviewText: "The Dog Who Saved Christmas" is the story of Zeus, a former police dog who is adopted by the Bannisters, a family concerned about being robbed over the holidays. We soon discover that Zeus has a psychological problem though, and it's one that prevents him from being any good as a guard dog. Due to an on the job trauma, Zeus is afraid to bark. Being useless as a guard dog makes him unwanted by the family's matriarch, Belinda, and she is determined to return him to the pound after Christmas, despite the rest of the family's love for the dog. It's up to Zeus to prove himself during a Christmas robbery that two bungling burglars have been planning for a while."The Dog Who Saved Christmas" is an adequate television Christmas movie fit for the family audience. It has some cute ideas and some genuinely funny moments, often due to what seems to be a lot of improv by the actors and a lot of awkwardness that may or may not have been intentional. There are some annoying factors too. Sometimes the jabbering of the dumber burglar can be tiring, and there's something about the voice over of Mario Lopez as Zeus (yes, we hear his thoughts, or dog talk, here much like in Disney's Homeward Bound: The Incredible Journey) that seems more obviously done after the fact than on big screen releases. I'm not sure why this problem exists, but I think it's a direct to video or made for TV thing, as it reminds me of the trailers for the Buddies films. Anyway, if you can get past this, the performances are mostly pretty good. Gary Valentine and Elisa Donovan are great as the parents. Though, you will find yourself double-taking a lot, as Gary seems a bit like a clone of Kevin James. Elisa, on the other hand, I never have been too into her before, but she is super gorgeous here. Dean Cain is great as the smarter of the two dumb crooks, and Mario Lopez does a sincere and decent job as Zeus, whom you do feel for in the film, even though some of the writing for him could have been better and there's that problem I mentioned before of it sounding too much like something recorded in a sound booth later. Also worth noting are Adrienne Barbeau and Mindy Sterling, who were very good in their respective roles. One area I really want to give the film extra credit for is that it was better than I originally expected. Yeah, I'm only giving it three stars, but I didn't expect to give it that many, and I almost feel like giving it 3 and a half (but not quite like rounding up). The reason I thought it was better than expected is that it didn't end up just a whole film of 2 burglars falling into booby traps a la Home Alone. That happens, but it is not much of the film at all. There is more attention paid to the theme of getting over past traumas and not letting them define your life and cause you to miss out on other things. So, nice job on that. This may not be on par with Christmas TV movies from my childhood, but it's certainly got its pluses.The DVD of "The Dog Who Saved Christmas" is presented in widescreen and includes a commentary with some of the filmmakers and stars, a behind the scenes look at Mario Lopez recording his dialogue, and the film's trailer. Nice extras for an ABC Family Channel movie.
summary: The Low Budget is Really Felt, but Good Cast and Some Genuine Chuckles and Heart

reviewText: The Dog Who Saved Christmas is just exactly how other reviewers described:  badly written and not very interesting.  I found it to be too predictable, and casting was awful."Zeus" is a former rescue dog who ends up in a shelter.  The Bannister family is worried about frequent robberies in their neighborhood, so they adopt Zeus.  Only problem is, Zeus doesn't bark.  And, predictably, he runs into the family while they are carrying a huge gingerbread house, and drinks out of the toilet, etc.So even though the dad and two odd-looking children really love the dog, they plan on taking him back to the pound because of the doggity things he does.  Meanwhile, they leave him alone in their house while they go to visit grandmother on Christmas Eve.  I mean, who leaves an unruly dog alone in their home?  Nobody does.So these bumbling robbers, who have been breaking in and robbing houses in the nearby vicinity of the Bannister house, decide to rob them.  During the day.  Sure they would.  I mean, the cops are looking for robbers and these guys just drive right up to the house, park on the street and go inside the home, where they spend hours inside - eating food and playing pool, etc.  How likely is that?  Not very.They muzzle Zeus, and detain him for seemingly hours, while they stumble around the house, bumping into each other and commenting on family photos, playing pool, etc.  Zeus decides to get rid of his fear of barking, described more in detail during the movie, but I had already lost interest at that point.  Blah Blah Blah, yadda yadda yadda, and Zues saves the day.And then the Bannister family decide to keep him, because he's a hero who caught robbers, and he won't have to go to the pound and be put down for not barking, and drinking out of the toilet, etc.This movie is seriously ridiculous and I hate the way they nonchalantly adopt a pet and then decide, after a few minor incidents, to take the dog back to the pound, where in real life, he'd face certain death.  That's a bad message.  Dogs shouldn't have to be heroes to stay alive.Enough said.  Do not waste your time on this one.
summary: This one was a waste of time

reviewText: The premise of the movie is simple. After burglaries on their street, a family decides to adopt a dog. They do, but the dog, a former K-9 canine, no longer barks because of a trauma when he actually worked on the job. The family has to go visit relatives, and burglars decide to target the house. There are obvious parallels toHome Alone, especially in the would-be crooks, who bumble their way through the operation, to any movie with talking animals, and toMarley and Me (Single-Disc Edition)(which, as another reviewer astutely pointed out, has an almost identical cover).This is clearly an effort aimed at children, and in that sense it might work. However, for adults and, no doubt, teens, it simply isn't worth seeing. There really isn't much heart in the film; there's very little Christmas spirit, and there aren't many true laughs. In anticipation of being told to take a movie for what it is, I will respond that there is no reason for a children's movie not to be enjoyable for people of all ages. ThinkToy Story, for example.
summary: Home Alone meets Marley and Me meets Look Who's Talking

reviewText: This was a cute, family-friendly Christmas film, about the Bannister family that adopts a retired K-9 dog from the pound, and grow to love him.  The dog is named Zeus, and the family calls him Zeusis for fun: he is pretty much everything they want in a dog, except the 'mom' of the family (played by Mindy Sterling) wants a watchdog, as there has been a recent break-in, in the neighborhood, and she doesn't believe that Zeus is a good guard dog.The rest of the family spend the movie trying to convince her that he is a good guard dog, only Zeus won't bark: the family is just thinking that they may have to give him up, when two bumbling criminals break into the family home, and Zeus has a chance to prove himself: will he be able to stop the bad guys?  will the Bannister's decide to keep him for good?I enjoyed this cute, family Christmas film: it was a bit bland though, and a little strange that there was no CGI or special effects of any kind on the talking animals like Zeus: they just basically sat there, and then a voice was done for them (in Zeus's case, by Mario Lopez): it was goodhearted, cheery & fun, and I liked it, but didn't love it: it was a tad too forgettable for that...would recommend to families searching for a movie to watch together.
summary: Cute family Christmas film ~ liked it but didn't love it...
Title: N/A

reviewText: I watched this movie with my 4 year old daughter and my 2 year old son, both of whom adore dogs and dog movies, and none of us were very impressed with this one.The story is about a former police dog named Zues (voiced by Mario Lopez) who is adopted by a family who live in a ridiculously large house. The mother (played by Emily Donovan whom you may remember as Amber in the '90's hit Clueless) only wants the dog as a gaurd dog but since the pooch can't/won't bark she sees no value in him (even though her two kids adore him) and wants the dog to go back to the pound. The family leaves for an overnight trip to the gramdmother's house and leaves the dog at home. From this point on, the dog attempts to run off a pair of burglars 'Home Alone' style...only really lame. He drops some ornaments and flour on their head and then gets muzzled and tied up. Obviously, he prevails in the end and the family decides to keep him.The plot is weak, the dialouge is really cheesy and a lot of what they say doesn't even make sense. Not to mention the burglars - they are really obnoxioius. The voice over for the dog is badly done in my opinion. There is a lot of dialouge for the dog that does not match the dogs actions at all. For example, the dog will be "saying" something in a really exciting voice but the dog in the movie looks like he's about to fall asleep. To me, that is just sloppy film making. I mean, atleast get a shot of him while he's wagging his tail or something!I had to force myself to sit through it and my kids lost interest pretty quickly. When it comes to kids movies, I try to base a lot of my rating on how my kids reacted to the movie since it is for them...they have not asked to watch this movie again and we've had it for over a month. This movie gets a 2 stars from me instead of 1 only because I feel sorry for Gary Valentine (love him on Chelsea Lately!)
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Dog Who Saved Christmas is a family friendly movie with a great message that suffers from okay acting from the humans and poor acting (or training) when it comes to the dog. It's a fine movie to watch with children and kept my attention as well. I wish I could give this three and a half stars but I gave it four because it is above average when it comes to the plot.The plot is simple,A dog that can't bark because of a past traumatic event foils some robbers only after overcoming this event. There is also a subplot regarding a neighbor who is not really what she seems to be.My big problem with the movie is the way the dog was trained.  The key to this movie is having a lovable dog interacting with everyone around him whether it be his owners or the robbers as well as performing human like actions. While the dog is cute I often felt he was looking at his trainer offstage rather than the people in the movie. There were a number of times when he seemed to be staring out into space when people were around him.People like it when animals become like humans and teach us about ourselves. Part of the premise of the movie is that the dog protects his home from robbers by moving things. For instance the dog drops Christmas ornaments and flour on the robbers.  Yet I did not see the dog grabbing the bag of flour and getting it on the robbers or taking the ornaments and dropping them on the robbers. You saw the dog and then the picture cut away and things happened.I really wonder if the producers did not have time to train the dog very well or if it was just too expensive to do so. I don't know how movies are made so maybe his scenes could have been edited better to make him seem more interested and make it seem like he was performing human-like actions.I want to make it clear that I like dogs and I liked the dog in the movie, but since the dog is the star of this picture I wish he had been trained better. It takes a special dog to interact with actors when there is a set full of people.While I am not an expert on dog training, there is a long history in the movies going back to Rin Tin Tin and Lassie and Benji where dogs were trained very well to perform on camera and interact with people. For me the dog was a disappointment.The human cast is fine.  The husband, wife and children seem like they are part of a family.  The crazy grandmother is believable as is the neighbor. The two robbers were okay as well.The acting was something you would see on a television show.  It was nothing special but it was okay.The plot and story was actually good. It is good for children and even adults to be reminded that any living thing can overcome past traumatic events and be a hero. It is good for children and adults to realize that strange neighbors may actually be nice. It is good to see a loving family at Christmas.This movie is worth watching with your family. It is child friendly. Even the robbers are not really scary.While this is no Home Alone it is still a good movie but it could have been so much better.
summary: Family Friendly Movie that has a Great Plot with Okay Acting by the Humans and Poor Acting/Training when it Comes to the Dog.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I really wanted to like this movie and it seemed to have stuff that I like. Christmas. Family. A family pet.Unfortunately that was not to be.I didn't care that the premise was already done. As the good king said "There is nothing new under the sun". What I did care about was that the jokes were not funny - too predictable and *they* were all done a thousand times before in a thousand movies that were better.And because I was bored before the first 15 minutes were up, I never got the connection to the movie, or any of characters that should have had me going "awww" at the appropriate times - which is all these movies really ask of the audience.So sorry that I didn't like it better.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "The Dog Who Saved Christmas" was originally released as a televised movie on the ABC Family Network.  Being a made for TV movie the production quality reflects its original medium but that said the video quality is decent enough that this shouldn't be an issue save for the most discriminating film buff.The story is a straight rip of 'Home Alone' but obviously geared for a dog loving audience.  Mario Lopez does an adequate voice over performance as Zeus, the dog who saves the day.  Most of the humor veers toward slapstick and silly gags and is perfectly appropriate for viewers of all age.
summary: Nice gift item for the dog lover in your life
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you are looking for a cute dog movie to keep the family entertained around Christmas, this will do the trick. It is somewhat of a knock off from the movie, Home Alone and it runs on a low budget. It's not a "bad" movie! The dog is of course, adorable!  For that alone, I'd watch it again!  The kids were happy and I guess that is what it comes right down to. I have a difficult time giving it above a 3 star as their are many other movies out there that have done better.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Entertaining movie for the family. If I had to sum up the movie in one phrase I'd say it was "Home Alone 5" but instead of a child being left behind this time we have a ex-K9 police dog that is suffering from mental trauma. Zeus is no longer on the force but has been adopted by a (surprisingly) normal family that is in need of a watchdog due to resent neighborhood home robberies. The family leaves the house on Christmas eve to visit Grandma and Zeus now alone. What could possibly happen?Unlike the first Home Alone movie slapstick is much milder and the crotch jokes have been left out. Except for some passing gas humor this movie should be okay for the younger kids.Gary Valentine plays the father and for me gets all the good laughs. The under-the-breath comments reminded me of myself which caused quite a few out-loud laughs on my part. The directing leaves a lot to be desired but since it was made for TV and since your kids really won't care it's not a big deal.I'd say the movie is worth owning. The kids will enjoy it way more then you will but compared to must movies that are passed as "family movies" you won't role your eyes when they want to watch it.
summary: Good made-for-TV Dog Lover Family Movie
Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie is pretty much Home Alone 4 (or 5, or whatever its up to) but with a dog. I think they are trying to capitalize on the popularity of the Marley movie (even the DVD covers look similar!)Zeus the dog is an ex-police K9 turned pound puppy who gets taken home by a family at Christmas.  The dad and kids love the dog but the mom isn't sure she wants one around the house.  To make matters worse, they think he might be too friendly to be a good watch dog.But when a pair of bungling burglars set their sights on the family home...  Well,  you did see Home Alone,  right?  Kind of predictable.... but overall a harmless family holiday movie.

reviewText: This movie is pretty much Home Alone but with a dog in place of a boy.  The storyline was cute but the acting was pretty bad.  I agree with another reviewer who said it was cheesy.  This movie gave me the impression that some High School kids were directing & filming it.  I had to laugh when I saw the credits roll by at the end because there were many different groups of people with the same last names.  Seemed like a big family got together & said "Hey, let's make a movie".  Overall the movie was o.k.  Kid's will more than likely enjoy it.  Adults will shake their heads at the bad acting but will probably make it through to the end if watching it as a movie.
summary: Home Alone but with Pretty Bad Acting...
Title: N/A

reviewText: Some films are not made for certain age groups.  If you have a sophisticated kid, this may not appeal to you.  Having said that, this is an enjoyable film for the innocent.My kids laughed and laughed at the antics of Zeus, Cain and major bonehead assistant in their silent film inspired comedy sequences.  Even the gullible father and mother add to the atmosphere of the feel good plot.  This is simple, but good film-making.The Bannister family will make a good addition to any childs film collection.  I would love to see Dean Cain take on an adult role soon.
summary: A great family film for pre-teens
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a cute, entertaining movie that was obviously shot on a budget. My daughter's first complaint was that the dogs' mouths didn't move. This is the first sign of many that the film is simply middle-of-road.The story is typical -- think "Home Alone", but with a dog, and you'll pretty much sum-up the plot. This is a story about good vs. bad, with very few side plots, and very little depth. As a result, however, it should be easy for young viewers to keep up with the story.Unfortunately, there are quite a few problems. For one, there's a pretty violent part where one of the evil characters wants to beat the dog with a golf club. The language during this scene is much harsher than it really needs to be, and even with the PG-rating, it's a deal-breaker for me.More than half-way through the film, my daughter asked "When will the dog save Christmas?" Although the plot is apparent, it really doesn't get started until the last third of the film. So it's a long journey.The editing is really weak. At times, I thought there were many scenes that should have just been cut. It seemed like there were scenes that were added because perhaps the film was too short. Even the plot sometimes seems constructed "on-the-fly". There are several scenes that will leave you thinking "why didn't the dog just..." because there are things so obvious, you don't understand how the director/writers missed it.Mario Lopez, as the voice of Zeus, is entertaining. The cast is OK, but at times, due to the way the script is written, the family seems entirely "too perfect". As a result, this is a film that you can watch once -- MAYBE twice -- but after that, I'm sure it will wear thin really fast.
summary: watchable once, entertaining for the whole family

reviewText: This is a simple, improbable story about a dog that is gotten from the pound to be a family guard dog; but he won't bark. There is the bumbling good natured father, the efficient mother and the children - a boy and girl. The family leaves the house on Christmas and Zeus the dog cannot go to grandma's; so he stays and the blundering 2 burglars break into the house and as the title says - the dog saves Christmas...gee sounds like a movie most have already hear of.The DVD itself has audio commentary with the producer and the 2 stars Gary Valentine and  Elisa Donovan. It is definitely the worst director's commentary I have ever heard; there is so much laughter and talking over each other, most of the time none of my family could understand what they were saying - at least they were having a good time. There are English subtitles for the deaf and hearing impaired; also a short bit with Mario Lopez dubbing for the dog's voice. Sneak peaks of' All Roads Lead to Home' and the `Velveteen Rabbit' and Dolby surround 5.1 sound are also included.If you liked Home Alone then you'll probably like this simple little movie which also includes bloopers at the ending.
Title: N/A
